movie_name: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones

reviews.review: Attack of the Clones is easily the worst of George Lucas’ Star Wars films. Plagued by wooden dialogue, a forced romance, aged CGI, and countless other flaws that critics have pointed out for decades, it struggles on many fronts. However, the core story of Palpatine’s political manipulation and Obi-Wan’s detective arc offer compelling threads, supported by strong world-building. Ultimately, it’s not a good film—but I still look at it fondly, maybe just out of nostalgia
Better action and fight scenes compared to the first movie.

"Star Wars: Attack of the Clones" delivers plenty of exciting action, boosted by CGI that, while impressive in scope, sometimes leans too heavily into video game-like visuals that can feel awkward in a live-action setting. Hayden Christensen’s performance as Anakin Skywalker is a bit questionable, yet it oddly fits the character’s conflicted nature. The romantic subplot is famously awkward—so much so that it becomes oddly endearing in its own way. Despite its flaws, the film stands out as an exciting and memorable chapter in the Star Wars saga, offering not just adventure but also a surprisingly meaningful and spiritual message that gives the story added depth.
Other than some good moments here and there, this is a very weak movie.

Improved spectacle in a blur that sensationally deepens the lore and satisfy fanatical excitement with manageable emotional touch, whilst much of the deliverance comes across as ignorant when effortlessly glancing at the screenplay’s processing characterization. (B)

Despite some poorly written romance dialogue, "Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones" excels in worldbuilding and action in the latter half. Additionally, it cleverly constructs the origins of the Galactic Empire.

A second film in a series often doubles down on the first film; unfortunately George Lucas, clearly a man in desperate need of someone to tell him 'No' by this stage, doubles down on all the wrong things. Even more CGI, that's often even more badly executed; a meandering plot and embarrassing screenplay that scarcely bothers to develop characters; whole sections where almost nothing happens, and when things do happen, it's unclear why it's happening at all. Worst are the scenes between Padame and Anakin, which seem to be written by a 12-year old boy with an underdeveloped understanding of human relationships. The final 30-minutes or so are passably enjoyable, with a degree of peril, visual flair and a much needed sense of fun amidst all the po-faced nonsense. But it's too little, much too late to save a film that scarcely works on any level.

After the dissapointment of The Phantom Menace there still remained a slim gimmer of hope that Attack of the Clones might salvage this prequal trilogy. Instead, in some ways its actually worse. It is a movie against which we can level the most fatal criticism - its boring. It drags on for over 2 hours, with the plot moving from jedi detective story, to teenage romance to a confrontation with the least convicing enemy in Star Wars history. Again, the opening scrawl should be warning enough. The enemy in this case being a seperatist movement, looking to break away from the Republic. How this is different to the Rebellion looking to break away from the Empire in later movies is never really explained. Some attempt is made to remove elements of the earlier movies which did not work. Anakin as an annoying child is replaced by Anakin as an annoying teen. The much hated Jar Jar Binks is sidelined into a minor role, where he can be blamed for inadvertently causing the rise of the Empire. As in the previous film though, the dialogue is atrocious and the story lacks any sense of pace or drama. CGI takes over much of the action with CGI droids fighting CGI clones, its more like watching someone play a Star Wars video game. It's hard to feel invested in any of the characters. This is definitely one of the worst Star Wars movies ever made. It fails on every level and its most impressive legacy is that it subsequently led to the sale of so many toys, cartoons and video games based on something so fatally flawed.

Star Wars: Episode II Attack of the Clones, is a film that most people like to judge base on its dullness or a split narrative. Continuation of corruption, dragging peaceful people to an unnecessary war, young (forbidden) love, and your space protectors being put into combatant generals position for the 1st time ever. All while, the main bad guy behind the scene is orchestrating all of it with pawns for his own rise to power. So much to fit into a movie, that at first glance people forgot, it’s the start of a major war with a 10 years gap from Episode I. All aspects leading into the war, didn't get the screen time it deserved but overall well executed for those who don't like to be spoon fed every detail, but give glimpses and leave the audience’s imagination take the wheel as the war carries on.
Still a great movie. It would be an Oscar movie in 2024.

And I remember thinking one thing back then... "OH MAN OBI-WAN IS SO COOL!!!" Yeah, Obi-wan's story arc in this movie, his whole... detective story is done pretty well in my opinion, And his confrontations with jango are pretty cool scenes... Is this movie a master piece? No. Is it stupid at times? Yes. Is it one of the worst movies ever made? NO. I think it's underrated. I may be one of it's few defenders but hey, someone's gotta root for the underdog!

10 years after the previous film Anakin Skywalker is all grown up, he's learned much of the ways of the Force from his mentor Obi-Wan Kenobi but is still rash, arrogant, and rushing to be great Padme Amidala has resigned her position of queen of Naboo and taken a senator's seat of the Old Republic but an assassin is after her in the form of a bounty hunter named Jango Fett Kenobi tracks him down on the system Kamino where he finds a clone army has been in development in secret after Syfo Dias passed away Meanwhile Anakin is assigned to protect Padme, but he still has nightmares about his mother in trouble back on Tatooine This sets him on a path that will determine his actions saving the galaxy and facing the darkness in his heart Even after this coming out after 20 years George Lucas still has trouble showing he can actually write and direct actors yet he still tries to lay out all the pieces of the puzzle It remains, in more ways than one, a low point for the franchise, and one that has been recontextualized a great deal since its initial release There's no doubt the acting is bad, the dialogue is stilted, the romance is flat, and these lines Hayden Christensen has to say are boring, monotone, and lifeless It's also the longest and slowest of the prequels Yet the film still looks visually pleasing, the clone attack on Geonosis is the highlight Great to see Yoda fight in action and to see Christopher Lee as Darth Tyrannus bringing gravitas It's one of the first movies to be entirely shot in digital with good editing, framework, and Williams' score doesn't disappoint Thank god this paved the way for 'Revenge of the Sith' to be so much better And there is an eternal lesson contained within this movie that applies now more than ever, as Hollywood simply cannot get out of its own way a lot of the time in its pursuit of box office dollars earned on the backs of franchise films That lesson is that just because something is attached to a property that people care about does not guarantee success Im glad this expanded the canon with Jango Fett and the storm troopers' origins It's like a sand analogy; incorporating campy elements into a sci-fi blockbuster Once you get a little campy, it tends to spill over into everything

So after all of these years, seeing this movie after The Phanom Menace, this movie isn't as boring as most folks give this credit for. Admittedly, there were some cool parts ranging from the chase scene back on Coruscant, seeing Anakin and Padme bond over while falling in love, seeing the Clones on Kamino on how they were born and learn before they were sent to any war, seeing Jango Fett being a badass like Obi-Wan throughout the film to the arena over at Geonosis and even the fight against Count Dooku. But I do understand most of the cons that are in this movie. Half of the script isn't the greatest, some of the dialogue hasn't aged well as twenty years had passed and some of the scenes do feel a little too goofy on their own. It is better than the first movie, as the Prequel Trilogy goes even before the best one arrives. 6/10.

There's a disconnect between the lovable Jake Owen and the tyrannical figure he'd later become, and it's not Episode 2's Anakin.

Just like The Phantom Menace, this has aged quite well. The opening scenes on Coruscant are quite good. But then it splits in two. Anakin & Padme’s romance is some of the worst Star Wars to date (but it’s still better than the Sequel Trilogy). It feels unnatural and forced. But that’s not the fault of Hayden Christensen and Natalie Portman. Although sand is coarse, rough and irritating. But what Obi-Wan Kenobi was doing for this whole movie was great. I loved going to Kamino then discovering Geonosis. Which is when the movie gets the strongest. Everything on Geonosis was fantastic. This movie also introduced Count Dooku (or Darth Tyrannus), who is an absolutely phenomenal villain. Overall, this may have a terrible romance side plot, but Obi-Wan’s adventures and everything on Geonosis definitely carry this movie. 6/10

Another frustrating watch. While you could see the potential for something greater, the execution leaves so much to be desired. Attack of the Clones certainly ups the ante of its predecessor. The action scenes are more thrilling and the lightsaber duel are decent enough. There is an attempt to further develop certain main characters, particularly Anakin, as we see his inevitable fall to the Dark Side start to to take shape. Generally the performances are great (minus Hayden, but we'll get to him, BELIEVE THAT). John Williams always delivers with his Scores but I feel the need to acknowledge his work whenever it's necessary. The man doesn't put a foot wrong. However, there are more cons than pros. Firstly, the pacing, again. This film is under two and a half hours but feels at least 45 minutes longer. Is it as boring as The Phantom Menace? Possibly, but it's got more problems than that one does. Secondly is the dialogue. You don't need me to tell you that most of it comes off as forced and unnatural and the worst offender of this is Hayden Christensen. I don't know if it was the script or the direction, but some scenes are genuinely terrible. They'd make Tommy Wiseau jealous. There's also some of the inconsistencies and moments which feel super contrived. Lastly, there is the overuse and poor quality of the CGI. Again, I know it was the early 2000s, but it's just ridiculous how bad most of it is. It's as if I'm watching a Disney Channel Original Movie. George really needed some sort of oversight. In conclusion, Attack of the Clones is in my view possibly the worst of the Prequels (admittedly that's ablow bar) and a frustratingly disappointing film.

Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones is a polarizing chapter in the beloved franchise that suffers from uneven storytelling and clunky dialogue. While the film offers impressive visual effects and action sequences, it falls short in character development and narrative coherence. Hayden Christensen's portrayal of Anakin Skywalker lacks the depth and charisma needed to fully connect with audiences, and the romantic subplot between Anakin and Padmé feels forced and lacking in chemistry. However, the film does introduce memorable new characters, such as Jango Fett and Count Dooku, adding some intrigue to the plot. Despite its flaws, "Attack of the Clones" does have its moments of excitement and nostalgia for Star Wars fans, making it a passable addition to the saga, albeit one that may leave some longing for the magic and storytelling prowess of the original trilogy.

10 years after the previous film Anakin Skywalker is all grown up, he's learned much of the ways of the Force from his mentor Obi-Wan Kenobi but is still rash, arrogant, and rushing to be great Padme Amidala has resigned her position of queen of Naboo and taken a senator's seat of the Old Republic but an assassin is after her in the form of a bounty hunter named Jango Fett Kenobi tracks him down on the system Kamino where he finds a clone army has been in development in secret after Syfo Dias passed away Meanwhile Anakin is assigned to protect Padme, but he still has nightmares about his mother in trouble back on Tatooine This sets him on a path that will determine his actions saving the galaxy and facing the darkness in his heart George Lucas still has trouble showing he can actually write and direct actors yet he still tries to lay out all the pieces of the puzzle It remains, in more ways than one, a low point for the franchise, and one that has been recontextualized a great deal since its initial release There's no doubt the acting is bad, the dialogue is stilted, the romance is flat, and these lines Hayden Christensen has to say are boring, monotone, and lifeless It's also the longest and slowest of the prequels Yet the film still looks visually pleasing, the clone attack on Geonosis is the highlight Great to see Yoda fight in action and to see Christopher Lee as Darth Tyrannus bringing gravitas It's one of the first movies to be entirely shot in digital with good editing, framework, and Williams' score doesn't disappoint Thank god this paved the way for 'Revenge of the Sith' to be so much better And there is an eternal lesson contained within this movie that applies now more than ever, as Hollywood simply cannot get out of its own way a lot of the time in its pursuit of box office dollars earned on the backs of franchise films That lesson is that just because something is attached to a property that people care about does not guarantee success Im glad this expanded the canon with Jango Fett and the storm troopers' origins It's like a sand analogy; incorporating campy elements into a sci-fi blockbuster Once you get a little campy, it tends to spill over into everything

I still had a fantastic time watching this but I completely forgot about how bad some of the dialogue is. The romance between Anakin and Padme works, but it's not executed well. If they spent more time on their relationship, this movie could've been so much better then it was. Like I said, despite some of the dialogue really holding back this movie, there is a ton of stuff to love. The scenes with Kenobi on Kamino, the battle of Geonosis, and seeing Yoda duel Count Dooku are incredible. On top of that, George Lucas expands on his world-building from The Phantom Menace. Overall, this movie is very flawed but it features some of the best moments in Star Wars.

This movie is awful. It has almost nothing going for it, the romance is bland and makes no sense. The dialogue is wooden, and makes the characters come off as emotionless sociopaths which works against our ability to connect with them. The action is ok in certain areas, but its boring because like I said earlier we don't have enough of a connection with any of these characters to truly root for them. The CGI is not just very dated, but it was bad for the time as well, and heavily overused. The set design is sometimes ok, but the use of fake looking blue screen composite shots take you out of the movie. Not to mention how sterile everything looks, the Jedi Temple and senate buildings don't look like royal and historical places that have stood for generations. They all look way to clean and brand new and lack any kind of tactile feeling or sense of history. Every characters do incomprehensibly stupid and oddly complex things to service the plot. Its like the characters know how the story needs to end so they will go to any lengths to make that happen rather than it coming across naturally or through logical progression. This film tried to be better than its predecessor, by removing or de-emphasizing certain poorly received elements from the last one. But, it ended up being even worse because what little charm The Phantom Menace had is just gone here.

Even weaker than "Star Wars: Episode I- The Phantom Menace" (1999), "Star Wars: Episode II- Attack of the Clones" is an even more CGI overload to the senses. Weak dialogue and some dated effects by today's standard, are the least of it's issues. The 143 minute running time just becomes an over saturated mess of green screen and generic robots. While there are some scenes that are overly fleshed out and explained in tedious detail, the abundance of action in this film helps keep it moving forward but just becomes over jarring as the time goes on. It sets the stage for Revenge of the Sith to tie the two trilogies together into one seamless saga, which is about all it does.

Marginally better than Phantom Menace, if only for the lack of Jar Jar Binks and poor child acting. The dialogue is terrible, the humor often cringey, and the overreliance on CGI is as bad as it gets. But it scores points for a few strong scenes, such as the intrigue surrounding Kamino and the clone army, Anakin's slaughtering of the Sand People, and Obi Wan's space battle against Fett.

I do agree that this is the weakest of the six Star Wars movies, but it wasn't by all means a terrible movie. I will admit the dialogue is weak and gets nowhere at times, the plot isn't as well thought out and felt convoluted at best, Haydn Christensen does give a truly abysmal performance as Anakin and although the presence of Jar Jar Binks was toned down here his presence anywhere seemed jarring. Still despite the major flaws, it is a marvel to look at with stunning sets and impeccable CGI. The battle sequences are well choreographed, the pace is somewhat brisker than in Phantom Menace and the performances with the exception of Christensen are very good. Natalie Portman is quite captivating as Queen Padma, and displays a lot of emotional depth. Frank Oz is excellent as always as Yoda, and Ewen MacGregor is more at home here than he was in Phantom Menace. There is no doubt though that the acting honours go to Christopher Lee as the villainous Count Dooku. Then again, Lee is an exceptional actor who can act anything you throw at him. Plus John Williams' music was outstanding. Overall, a decent movie while the weakest of the Star Wars franchise. 6/10 Bethany Cox

Rating: D+ I don't know if I dislike THE PHANTOM MENACE more or ATTACK OF THE CLONES less, but I didn't feel the (endless) problems of episode II as much as I - Jar Jar being left aside helps tremendously, thank God. Still, the issues are so many that I can't fit them in a single paragraph. The dialogue is even worse in this one, mostly due to the cringeworthy romantic storyline between Anakin and Padmé. Some of the worst writing the big screen has ever witnessed. I'm usually quite defensive of acting performances, but Christensen is truly, deeply terrible here. There are more lightsaber fights, but none come even close to Maul's sequence in TPM. Once again, the overreliance on CGI elements/characters doesn't help the action set pieces, despite the visuals overall improvement. The score makes most scenes "look" better than they are. The screenplay is packed with logical inconsistencies, but it's the poor treatment of the all-powerful, wise Jedi that disappoints me. From their lack of awareness to the made-up, nonsensical rules about their ideology, I really don't know what Lucas had on his mind. Finally, the editing yet again. ATTACK OF THE CLONES is longer than it should. Captivating, important sequences are cut too short, while dull, exposition-heavy scenes are carried on for too long. There's a good movie in here somewhere. I just can't find it. However... Its positives somehow land better this time around. I find most of the action pretty solid. Anakin rescuing his mother is arguably one of the best scenes of the prequels. And again, less Jar Jar. I genuinely think it switches with THE PHANTOM MENACE ... at the bottom of my ranking, though.

In more recent years Clones has developed a reputation as the worst of the films in the Star Wars saga, but I couldn't disagree more with that assessment. In fact this is my favorite among the prequel films. It has this energy and style that just feels so undeniably "Star Wars." There's some thrilling action sequences, an intriguing plot, some breathtaking visuals and photography...and of course a top notch score, and that imaginative, visceral world that's so much fun to spend time in. It's not flawless though, there are some clunkier bits that interrupt the flow of the film, the effects themselves are nothing short of amazing for their time but have a tendency to feel uncanny as though the actors believe they're somewhere else... and your mileage may vary when it comes to the dialogue and romance (A common complaint that's never bothered me to the degree it clearly bothers others).

With dialogue that is unbearable to listen to and a story that is extremely convoluted, "Attack of the Clones" stands as the worst "Star Wars" movie to its date, providing some of the worst dialogue between characters in any movie ever made. The entire story tries to cram too much information into it, and it ends up jumping around a lot to try to fit everything into its run time. However, where I think that this film soars is in its action, especially the battle of Geonosis, which takes up the entire third act of the film. It is absolutely entertaining to watch and the CGI helps it out a lot. The new characters introduced are also very great, and the worldbuilding is some of the best. It's characters, though undeveloped, are interesting and watchable enough for me to bluntly enjoy the experience. I can also complement how it is not a carbon copy of his original work, and follows a different premise. I have to say, in conclusion, that Attack of the Clones is not a good movie, but nor is it bad. We have seen worse from the franchise.

After the disappointment that Star Wars Episode I was, I couldn't get myself to watch the second movie in the prequel trilogy. But the thing about Star Wars is that there is no way you can possibly hate the franchise no matter what it does. Even if there's one bad movie there's still a new hope (ba dm tss!), that probably the next movie does fix some stuff. And I can tell you with a guarantee that Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones is definitely not that kind of a movie. And no, I'm not scared of some kid marking my review unhelpful who probably lives in the basement of his parents' house. One problem that constantly plagues the Star Wars prequel trilogy is that most of the good stories happen while the camera is not on the characters. There is a scene where Kenobi and Anakin are in an elevator while going to save Padmé from an assassin and talking about their previous adventures. And trust me, all those adventures sound WAY more fun than what we are being made to watch. Most of the characters shown throughout the movie are there just for the sake of being there, without any amount of character development. That's not to say I absolutely dislike this movie. I really like the whole Jango Fett arc. It was one of the most memorable parts of the movie. There was also the colosseum fight which wasn't good but at least it was memorable. Also the part where C3PO accidentally falls on the assembly line and gets his head replaced by another robot. Other than that most scenes are easily forgettable, not as in I have forgotten they ever happened, but rather I have forgotten whether they happened in Episode II or III. I had to look up the scene I wrote in the above paragraph to make sure it happened in this movie. The CGI, once again is terrible. I don't know what's the problem with the cinematography of this movie. It makes it look so boring. And of course, here's the movie where Anakin and Padmé start getting, well. I don't know what's with Star Wars movies and accidental incest. I get it's supposed to be a space opera, but this goes a little too far. Also the acting is super campy. One person will finish the dialogue, then the next person will speak. And I think it's a good thing because of how high the background music is. If two people start speaking together it will become impossible to hear altogether. I had said that I'd try giving another watch to Star Wars: Episode I, which is hard because of how cringy Jar-Jar Binks. But here it's hard because only the Jango Fett scene was fun. This is, in my opinion, the worst Star Wars movie made by George Lucas. Trust me when I say I get no joy from saying all of this. I still had the courage to watch the franchise further, and I'm really glad I did since Revenge of the Sith really redeemed the trilogy for me.

This is a 3 Star worthy movie that is stretched to a runtime considerably longer than it should be. The movie itself is largely a bit entertaining by and large, even though it's really rather hollow, which makes the obvious time-stretching bits a bit more taxing.. What's really odd is that if you look at the Deleted Scenes, there are A LOT of well-written bits of Character-building that were cut from the movie, and I really, really cannot fathom why these were cut instead of some of the bits that made it into the movie, as these are EASILY some of the best moments in the movie. Like, truthfully, I kinda wish that they made an Extended Cut of this movie, because these Deleted bits, if placed back into the movie, would likely make the movie have more impact...It might still suffer from the poor pacing, but everything would actually have more meaning, which is the main thing that this movie lacks: A Purpose. Now, in terms of the movie itself, the dialogue is not of good quality, but it's more 'flat' and 'functional' rather than something the kind of dialogue that fancies itself brilliant but is actually dumb, and frankly, I prefer this kind of bad myself. The image is crisp and the use of HD filming, as this was one of the very first movies to ever do this, was certainly effective, and while much of the CGI certainly looks dated (admittedly some still looks good), the Composites in regards to how everything Practical and Digital fit together still holds up. The musical score is a bit better than that of Episode 1, as is the Acting, although the latter really just brings it from the low-end of Mediocre to mid-tier Mediocre. And lastly, the action is pretty good, but not on par with Episodes 3, 5 or 6. Sadly, the movie also focuses on a love story at the center, and it's really quite shallow and awkward, albeit I do think there's a couple of very small moments that do slightly work. But overall, this is just a somewhat unnecessary movie, as could've ultimately been made into a 15-30 minute story, but I think George Lucas simply wanted his Story to be in a particular place for his Final Chapter, which is certainly fine - the problem is just that this movie suffers as the result of it. Still, I don't remotely hate this movie - I'm just more than willing to admit that it suffers from many shortcomings.

6.75/10. Though an improvement over it's predecessor, writer/director George Lucas has a long way to go in restoring glory to this franchise. Some great action sequences, superb effects, and great art direction are to be expected from a 'Star Wars' picture, and this one delivered. The improvements over the first episode comes from the acting and plot line featuring Ewan McGregor, who develops Obi-Wan into the wiser, more recognizable Jedi master we know from the original trilogy while playing psuedo-detective for the bulk of the film. Christopher Lee as the primary villain is a treasure also a treasure in his role. The film sputters when it focuses on the ghastly love story between Jedi padawan Anakin Skywalker (Hayden Christensen) and Senator Padme Amidala (Natalie Portman). The forbidden love angle is so worn out and rife with cliche that it's difficult not to laugh at. Christensen portraying his young, dumb, and in love character more like a psychotic abuser is baffling. Portman's acting might have made sense had Anakin been portrayed correctly, but Christensen boxed her character into seeming foolish, unable to see the mad man before her eyes, and certainly not discerning enough to be a galactic senator. None of this is helped by the script, which gives the actors nothing to work with and is awful throughout. A mild improvement isn't strong enough evidence that Lucas should continue as the primary creative architect of this franchise.

SUPER-bland, airless computer graphics movie hampered by unfavorable comparison to a completely different (and more successful) movie aesthetic created in the Star Wars timeline twenty years earlier. "Classic" Star Wars characters (played by puppets or robotic props) appear, for instance the absurd "Yoda showdown" that shows how bad CGI animation, improbable storytelling and a general Big Hollywood Flair for shallow, sugary details can disappoint an audience. Critics at the time couldn't be bothered being nice to this one either; unfortunately none other than George Lucas was behind the wheel, suggesting whatever gift he had for tactile fantasy sequences and dynamic casting had completely left him at this point. The great concept artist Ralph McQuarrie from the original trilogy didn't appear either, replaced by someone that likes insectile, flimsy design and over-cluttered backgrounds. Motion picture release spawned retail toy items, low quality "Clone Wars" animated spinoff feature also.

Better than 'Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace', though 'Star Wars: Episode II – Attack of the Clones' is again rather underwhelming - if still good on its own merits. Liam Neeson is missed, with the likes of Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman, Hayden Christensen and Christopher Lee failing to set the world alight. McGregor does give the best performance of that quartet; Christensen possibly the weakest, though his character's story is probably the most interesting - or its overall arc, at least. Those onscreen aren't helped by the dialogue, which is very basic and run-of-the-mill. I found the score a little forgettable, even if it's still fun to hear the key pieces of it. The plot is watchable, but I did expect greater storytelling from these two follow-up releases to the original trilogy. The CGI is, marginally, an improvement on this film's predecessor.

Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones is a bad movie. The best parts of this movie are easily the music, Ian McDiarmid as The Emperor, Ewan McGregor as Obi-Wan Kenobi and of course, Sir Christopher Lee as Count Dooku otherwise known as Darth Tyranus. Other than that this movie is not good, the plot is somewhat passable, the performances are even worse than before (especially with Padme), the dialogue is atrocious and the CGI, while better than the CGI in TPM is beginning to age. Still better than the previous movie though.
